citations.narrative:
On June 3rd, 2024, 194 dogs and 99 cats arrived at Washington Dulles International Airport (Dulles, Virginia) from Kabul
International Airport (Kabul, Afghanistan). Pender Pet Retreat was an intermediate handler for this inspection.
During the inspection, animal handlers caused unnecessary distress for several dogs. The dogs were handled in a
fenced-in outdoor area while in transition to indoor primary enclosures. The handlers used leashes to move the dogs from
their transport enclosures into the building. Several dogs were reluctant to move on a leash and ended up being pulled by
the leash into the facility. Three dogs managed to escape their leashes. The gates to the fence were being opened and
closed while these animals were loose. No animals escaped the fenced area. Dogs that are handled in a manner that
exacerbates their distress during a stressful event can lead to increased aggression, refusal to move, and accidental
escape from their leash due to pulling backwards. All dogs were safely recaptured.
During transportation animals must be moved quickly and efficiently to avoid causing physical harm, additional behavioral
distress, and unnecessary discomfort. Correct by June 10, 2024.
This inspection was conducted at Dulles International Airport and the Intermediate Handler Facility. The exit interview was
conducted with handler representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
ROBERT MARKMANN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR
Rachel Perez-Baum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Dawn Fitzhugh, Veterinary Medical Officer n
